first place <u>cyanogen<\u>. The gas was pro 
cured by heating <s>by means of a lamp<\s>
cyanide of mercury introduced into 
a retort of glass by means of a lamp. <s>and kindled, when 
coming out of the apparatus.<\s> The 
flame of it may be fed either with oxygen 
or with air.
When a jet of cyanogen mixed with 
oxygen is kindled, in the interior part 
of the flame a most brilliant cone of 
a <s>whitisch<\s>whitish-violet light is seen, the limit 
between the ignited and the cold part 
of the jet. This cone exhibiting the spectrum 
of vapour of carbon best developed,
we conclude the cyanogen must be 
decomposed into carbon and nitrogen,
the carbon being in the gaseous con
dition, a moment before its combina 
tion with oxygen takes place. +
42. In order to prevent explosion of the 
mixture of cyanogen and oxygen, it is 
preferable that the jets of both gases 
meet from opposite si<s>te<\s>[des] before the slit 
of the spectral apparatus, forming 
there, if kindled, a brilliant flat vertical 
surface. The jet of cyanogen might be 
obtained directly from the retort, by the 
heating of which it is regulated. Thus 
we got, all being properly arranged, a splendid 
and richly coloured spectrum. Especially 
we distinguish <u>eight groups of bright lines<\u>,
+ Mr Allfield has the merit 
of having first stated, that 
spectra hitherto attributed 
to compound gaseous substances,
are to be referred to the 
vapour of Carbon itself.
(Paper read to the Royal Society 
June 1862)
